thread.title: Battle to be party for tech startups heats up with Ed Husic's reshuffle promotion
thread.title_full: Battle to be party for tech startups heats up with Ed Husic's reshuffle promotion | afr.com

author: Yolanda Redrup
title: Battle to be party for tech startups heats up with Ed Husic's reshuffle promotion
text:
Labor MP Ed Husic: "We're trying to send a message to startups that their existence is recognised." Alex Ellinghausen Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Yolanda Redrup Ed Husic's reputation as a tech enthusiast has been recognised with promotion to opposition parliamentary secretary of digital innovation and startups in a shadow cabinet reshuffle, raising the profile of startups within the Labor Party.
Mr Husic is now pitched against Liberal MP Wyatt Roy, who was recently given the role of Assistant Minister for Innovation by Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull.
The move indicates a growing focus on the importance of supporting tech startups within both major parties, as politicians try to lay the groundwork for post-mining boom prosperity.
Mr Husic said this was the first time startups had been recognised by title in an opposition ministerial line-up.
Mr Husic is now pitched against Liberal MP Wyatt Roy, who was recently given the role of Assistant Minister for Innovation by Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull. Alex Ellinghausen "As things cool off in the mining side of the economy we do need to look at new ways to boost growth and there's a recognition that startups have a big role to play," he said.
"Particularly working with Bill as a leader, we're trying to send a message to startups that their existence is recognised."
Labor policies Last month Labor announced a number of new startup targeted polices including entrepreneurial visas and a startup year for university students.
 Up to 2000 foreign university graduates and 2000 entrepreneurs wanting to start their own business would be able to come to Australia under the new visas.
The $5.5 million startup year policy would also let university students want to start their own business access a HELP loan of about $10,000 of funding.
"This is of practical assistance and it also signals to the wider community that we value entrepreneurs," Mr Husic said.
"It has to be interpreted as starting to break down the culture which works against startups. People are focused on getting into university or TAFE and into a salary or wage-based position and we're saying that if you have a good idea in university, we'll encourage you to pursue it."
Mr Husic said there were more startup policy announcements to come.
Different to small business "The sector wanted evidence that there is a distinct difference between small business and startups and this is it," he said.
"We've said publicly that innovation shouldn't wait for a federal election and we've put forward ideas that we're happy for the government to explore and take up themselves."
Mr Husic applauded the move by Mr Roy to hold a so-called Policy Hack alongside startup incubator BlueChilli this weekend. The event aims to bring together the startup and venture capital communities with policy makers to thrash out new ideas for improving conditions for startups.
But Mr Husic said his main focus would be on tackling access to talent and capital and fostering a strong startup ecosystem.
"The biggest thing we have to tackle now is the low rate of startup transformation in Australia," he said.
"We have the know how and the ingenuity and now we have to make it a reality, either by dealing with talent, capital flows, regulations that stand in the way or having a more reactive regulatory framework."
